review.title: Using Linear Constraints for Logic Program Termination Analysis
review.abstract: It is widely acknowledged that function symbols are an important feature in answer set programming, as they make modeling easier, increase the expressive power, and allow us to deal with infinite domains. The main issue with their introduction is that the evaluation of a program might not terminate and checking whether it terminates or not is undecidable. To cope with this problem, several classes of logic programs have been proposed where the use of function symbols is restricted but the program evaluation termination is guaranteed. Despite the significant body of work in this area, current approaches do not include many simple practical programs whose evaluation terminates. In this paper, we present the novel classes of rule-bounded and cycle-bounded programs, which overcome different limitations of current approaches by performing a more global analysis of how terms are propagated from the body to the head of rules. Results on the correctness, the complexity, and the expressivity of the proposed approach are provided.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: As a guideline for future work, we plan to examine how our techniques can be combined in a consistent way with the current termination criteria. As they look at programs from radically different points of view, it is interesting to examine how they can be integrated so that they can benefit from each other. To this end, it would be an interesting approach to integrate termination criteria into the general framework proposed in (Eiter et al. 2013) and examine their combination in such a framework. Another exciting topic would be the analysis of the relationships between the concepts of security (Eiter et al. 2013) and the concepts of boundaries that are not exceeded by termination criteria.

metadata.abstractText: It is widely acknowledged that function symbols are an important feature in answer set programming, as they make modeling easier, increase the expressive power, and allow us to deal with infinite domains. The main issue with their introduction is that the evaluation of a program might not terminate and checking whether it terminates or not is undecidable. To cope with this problem, several classes of logic programs have been proposed where the use of function symbols is restricted but the program evaluation termination is guaranteed. Despite the significant body of work in this area, current approaches do not include many simple practical programs whose evaluation terminates. In this paper, we present the novel classes of rule-bounded and cycle-bounded programs, which overcome different limitations of current approaches by performing a more global analysis of how terms are propagated from the body to the head of rules. Results on the correctness, the complexity, and the expressivity of the proposed approach are provided. Under consideration in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP).
